comments.commentBody: Sorry, to me the reversal, while encouraging, did nothing to undo the damage that was done in the public mind.  What the House Republicans have stated here is that corruption rules the day unless public outrage trumps the corruption.  What this reversal illustrates  is the need to continue to be vigilant and let public outrage be known at every turn when the Republicans and Trump attempt to fortify their oligarchy.  We should remember, so far, we still have a democracy in which the people's opinion can make a difference.  It is up to the public to protect that right.
me too!!

You say "It's hard for the adults to concentrate on running the country."
Please-adults-and presidents- don't TWEET!

Look down the list of comments, where are they from? California, Washington (Seattle) New York, New Jersey, Massachusetts - my advice to my fellow democrats would be to get in your car and drive to Pennsylvania, Ohio, Wisconsin and Michigan- there is another America out there that you are clueless about
Wrong-Pittsburgh. We still believe in honesty and ethics and a helping hand when needed-Go stillers!
Well, here's one from a red state. I took time today to write to my Representative and both Senators, expressing the unacceptability of this maneuver.
This Northeast Ohio voter from a non-competitive gerrymandered district disagrees with you.
He's going to have to do a lot of mucking out to do that.

I watched my mother die of cancer. She received palliative chemo for years, the last one about a few weeks prior to her passing. She could not say no to hope, but it was absurd at that point for anyone to sell it to her as hope. It just killed her.

The regular conversation my mom had with her doctors was about using chemo to extend her life. For awhile it did that. Eventually it just seemed to be a way for her to witness her own body dying very,very slowly and painfully.

The only part of the process that felt right to me was keeping vigil at her bedside. My family committed to never leaving her alone in those last weeks. We took shifts round the clock. My mom died with the comfort of connection to those who loved her and the dignity of being someone who mattered.

If you love someone who is dying, you must get up the learning curve fast on how to be a genuine caregiver, how to be present, how to honor your loved one and how to step in if the medical process seems to be overtaking your sacred space. Nothing is more precious.
They haven't started out great here, have they? Truth be told.

Ethical and Republican?
Dishonor and Disrepute?
Nobody is whining. They expect better from leaders. This hasn't started off well at all.

Porch Dad,

With all due respect, the fact the you just used so many labels leads me to believe you've been brainwashed into thinking that labeling a person substitutes for the more difficult task of dialogue.

I disagree with you about those labels. I also think that, sometimes, the medicine we need doesn't always taste good. Mr. Trump may be exactly what America needs at this point in history.

America was imploding long before Mr. Trump ran for presidential office.
Except Trump doesn't object to gutting the Ethics Committee. Just doesn't agree that it should be "first thing" on the agenda.
Yes, please stop tweeting every thought that pops into your head with no filter or censorship.
Exactly what I came here to say, tax returns included.

This was a nice, smooth, but A TAD challenging Wednesday. I still can't quite grasp "M M M." Are these to be taken as three iterations of the Greek letter MU? If so, it's a pretty awkward entry. Same thing with BRUSH PILES. I'm pretty sure the phrase would have made no sense to most of us if not for the late, unlamented administration of George W. Bush, who was uniformly described as "clearing brush" during his frequent retreats to his Texas ranch.

Sitting on five acres in rural Michigan, would that I could recapture my innocence of brush piles. It's a never-ending chore. Still, we haven't got it as bad as these folks: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/03/19/colorado-tumbleweed-problem-pho...

Part of my former life was creating/maintaining trails on forest lands. After a few weeks of clearing the brush the way that had seemed right to me, I suddenly came on the simple truth: find the way the scrub is growing; stomp on it with a well-booted foot in the perpendicular direction; grab low down; pull the whole darn thing up out of the ground at once. Then: put it on the BRUSH PILE.

Hee hee, very satisfying. I named a particular acre of our land after G.W.B. since I cleared it while listening to his second inaugural and that gave me all the power I needed to uproot many dozens of bushes...sadly, not the right bushes...

Good grief, Barry and Julia! It seems it grows (or whatever it does) faster than kudzu! It sure seems to be prlific.

I still don't know why anyone would choose clearing it as a vacation activity.

Nonetheless, entertaining reading. My favorite part was the advice to "beef up your string trimmer," which I gather doesn't mean anything close to what it sounds like.

Quotation marks are employed for a variety of purposes. Sometimes quotes just mean "so called", with the specific intention of communicating that the words quoted are not true, as opposed to an intention of referring to a specific speaker.
http://www.thepunctuationguide.com/quotation-marks.html#otherusesofquota...

Angry missives from constituents, an upbraiding from party leaders and pointed tweets from President-elect Donald J. Trump led to the reversal.

Nice writing and summation of nothing more than poor strategy, tactics and timing. The Ethics Office does not have to be dismantled. It only has to be played correctly and in this case rightly.

Let's report the truth. The Republicans now feel the burn and with that feeling out will come the matches to be applied to the Constitution, Bill of Rights, common sense and simple dignity. All decency, democracy and freedom will go out the window into the swamp of their own making.

The Republicans did not reverse themselves. They decided to delay what will be inevitable under Trump: wholesale looting of the government and public purse, destruction of civil and human rights and a new morality which says that owning and controlling 99% of the wealth and income is not enough.

As the saying goes, Too much of a good thing is not enough.
I rarely met rich people who think they have enough.

The Ethics Office is a cover to be used only when one of its own is out of step with the rest. That is not ethics. It is immorality with a new conservative Christian facade.

In his university scam, the enrolling losers are given an ugly LOL lesson in how to get yourself signed up for empty promises and shine and an AG is who you bribe to keep her from investigating.

As to paying your workers and contractors, stiffing is the course to go.

As for your own "charity", not paying into it yourself but taking out that what others pay in for your own bizz expenses is Trump's idea of being ethical.

Making up scary scenes in inner cities or New Jersey is his ethical standard for cheap political gain, in defiance of meticulously researched stats or actual witnesses.

Birtherism. A Clinton thing.

If gazillion profits for befriended polluters are affected, Trump's ethics prompt him to deny the one science field relevant to their profit flow Big Oil and its offshoots forgot to infiltrate and rig or prevent from being carried out at all.

Introducing yourself to a woman kissing and groping all over her the Don deems ethical for a celebrity, since the young things are so intimidated by the eventual setbacks for them if they resist, they give the 35 year old halfgod a free pass.

Dealing with political opponents by having your crowds rant "Lock her up!" and asking foreign states to hack her communication is ethically impeccable as justice standard.

Concerning Congressional ethics a show is put up for the public while handily discrediting the oversight without substantiating an iota.

Be tax "smart", profile on races and religions and no ethical end. None.

comments.commentBody: I want all of their financial reports out every year. I'm just tired of this.
I'm afraid Trump isn't capable of a reasoned rebuttal. He is an unfortunate reflection of much of the electorate.

In other words, business as usual?
Actually, I don't think it's a bad sign about Trump, only about Congress. The Republicans there don't seem to understand that Trump didn't get elected to allow more of the same old, same old, and I think there will be some tussles before they have it straight who's in charge. It should be interesting to watch.
Right on the nail!

Pass the pipe or whatever you are smoking.

Our lawmakers are not above the law: they are below it.
68 ethics cases in seven years is an appalling high number. Someone needs to train our lawmakers more effectively
It seems that any party with too much power will in the end kill themselves.
Hopefully before they do irreparable harm.

You're right, Iona. Where are his tax returns? Trump had nowhere else to go for money because he's so over-leveraged. So what does he do? He turns to the American people for his next scheme. He may have hit a goldmine this time because of a supine American people who were dazzled by fool's gold. In the meantime, he can't sleep because when he closes his eyes late at night, he sees his house of cards empire collapsing in his mind.

I bet it's hard work being The Donald, having to obfuscate 24/7.
